com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya.args

Class ArrayArgs

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya.args.ArrayArgs

  • public final class ArrayArgs
extends Object
    Static methods to check array arguments.

    See ObjectArgs for an overview.

    Author:
    Kevin Connor ARPE (kevinarpe@gmail.com)

    • Method Detail

      • checkLengthRange

        @FullyTested
public static <T> T[] checkLengthRange(T[] ref,
                                   int minLen,
                                   int maxLen,
                                   String argName)
        Tests if an array reference is not null and its length within specified range. Length is defined as the number of elements.
        Parameters:
        ref - an array reference
        minLen - minimum number of elements (inclusive). Must be non-negative.
        maxLen - maximum number of elements (inclusive). Must be non-negative.
        argName - argument name for ref, e.g., "strList" or "searchRegex"
        Returns:
        the validated array reference
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if ref is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if minLen < 0,
        or if maxLen < 0,
        or if minLen > maxLen,
        or if number of elements in ref is outside allowed range
        See Also:
        ObjectArgs.checkNotNull(Object, String), checkMinLength(Object[], int, String), checkMaxLength(Object[], int, String), checkExactLength(Object[], int, String)

      • checkNotEmpty

        @FullyTested
public static <T> T[] checkNotEmpty(T[] ref,
                                String argName)
        Tests if an array reference is not null and not empty (size >= 1). Length is defined as the number of elements.
        Parameters:
        ref - an array reference
        argName - argument name for ref, e.g., "strList" or "searchRegex"
        Returns:
        the validated array reference
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if ref is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if number of elements in ref is zero
        See Also:
        checkLengthRange(Object[], int, int, String), checkMinLength(Object[], int, String)

      • checkMinLength

        @FullyTested
public static <T> T[] checkMinLength(T[] ref,
                                 int minLen,
                                 String argName)
        Tests if an array reference is not null and has a minimum length. Length is defined as the number of elements.
        Parameters:
        ref - an array reference
        minLen - minimum number of elements (inclusive). Must be non-negative.
        argName - argument name for ref, e.g., "strList" or "searchRegex"
        Returns:
        the validated array reference
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if ref is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if minLen < 0,
        or if number of elements in ref is outside allowed range
        See Also:
        checkLengthRange(Object[], int, int, String)

        Parameters:

        or if number of elements in ref is outside allowed range

        @FullyTested
public static <T> T[] checkExactLength(T[] ref,
                                   int exactLen,
                                   String argName)
        Tests if an array reference is not null and has an exact length. Length is defined as the number of elements.
        Parameters:
        ref - an array reference
        exactLen - exact number of elements (inclusive). Must be non-negative.
        argName - argument name for ref, e.g., "strList" or "searchRegex"
        Returns:
        the validated array reference

        or if number of elements in ref is outside allowed range

      • checkElementsNotNull

        @FullyTested
public static <T> T[] checkElementsNotNull(T[] ref,
                                       String argName)
        Tests if an array reference is not null and each element is not null.
        Parameters:
        ref - an array reference
        argName - argument name for ref, e.g., "strList" or "searchRegex"
        Returns:
        the validated array reference
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if ref (or any element) is null
        See Also:
        ObjectArgs.checkNotNull(Object, String), CollectionArgs.checkElementsNotNull(java.util.Collection, String)

      • checkNotEmptyAndElementsNotNull

        @NotFullyTested
public static <T> T[] checkNotEmptyAndElementsNotNull(T[] ref,
                                                     String argName)
        This is a convenience method for checkNotEmpty(Object[], String) and checkElementsNotNull(Object[], String). This method is useful to check variable argument lists (var args).

      • checkAccessIndex

        @FullyTested
public static <T> int checkAccessIndex(T[] ref,
                                   int index,
                                   String arrArgName,
                                   String indexArgName)
        Tests if an array reference is not null and an index is valid to access an element.
        Parameters:
        ref - an array reference
        index - index of element to access. Must be non-negative.
        arrArgName - argument name for ref, e.g., "strList" or "searchRegex"
        indexArgName - argument name for index, e.g., "strListIndex"
        Returns:
        the validated index
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if ref is null
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - if index < 0,
        or index >= ref.length
        See Also:
        checkInsertIndex(Object[], int, String, String)

      • checkInsertIndex

        @FullyTested
public static <T> int checkInsertIndex(T[] ref,
                                   int index,
                                   String arrArgName,
                                   String indexArgName)
        Tests if an array reference is not null and an index is valid to insert an element.
        Parameters:
        ref - an array reference
        index - index of element to insert. Must be non-negative.
        arrArgName - argument name for ref, e.g., "strList" or "searchRegex"
        indexArgName - argument name for index, e.g., "strListIndex"
        Returns:
        the validated index
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if ref is null
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - if index < 0,
        or index >= ref.length
        See Also:
        checkAccessIndex(Object[], int, String, String)

      • checkIndexAndCount

        @FullyTested
public static <T> void checkIndexAndCount(T[] ref,
                                      int index,
                                      int count,
                                      String arrArgName,
                                      String indexArgName,
                                      String countArgName)
        Tests if an array reference is not null, and an index and count is valid to access elements.
        Parameters:
        ref - an array reference
        index - index of element to access. Must be non-negative.
        count - number of elements to access, starting from index. Must be non-negative.
        arrArgName - argument name for ref, e.g., "strList" or "searchRegex"
        indexArgName - argument name for index, e.g., "strListIndex"
        countArgName - argument name for count, e.g., "strListCount"
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if ref is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if index < 0,
        or if count < 0
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - if index >= ref.length,
        or if index + count > ref.length

      • checkFromAndToIndices

        @FullyTested
public static <T> void checkFromAndToIndices(T[] ref,
                                         int fromIndex,
                                         int toIndex,
                                         String collectionArgName,
                                         String fromIndexArgName,
                                         String toIndexArgName)
        Tests if an array reference is not null, and 'from' and 'to' indices are valid to access elements.

        This test method was written for index pairs used by List.subList(int, int).

        Parameters:
        ref - a collection reference
        fromIndex - first index of element to access. Must be non-negative.
        toIndex - one greater than last index of element to access. Must be non-negative.
        collectionArgName - argument name for ref, e.g., "strList"
        fromIndexArgName - argument name for fromIndex, e.g., "strListFromIndex"
        toIndexArgName - argument name for toIndex, e.g., "strListToIndex"
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if ref is null
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - if fromIndex < 0,
        or if toIndex < 0,
        or if fromIndex >= ref.length,
        or if toIndex > ref.length
